questions.text: Who listed the four cardinal signs of inflammation?
questions.solution:
The four cardinal signs of inflammation were first listed by Aulus Celsus. He was a Roman medical writer of the first century AD. These are:

  1. Rubor - redness
  2. Tumour - swelling
  3. Calor - heat
  4. Dolor - pain

These signs are the hallmarks of acute inflammation.

Rudolf Virchow added the fifth clinical sign of inflammation, loss of function, functio laesa.

questions.text:
Which of the following stimuli can trigger an inflammatory response?
  1. DNA breakdown products
  2. Microorganisms
  3. Foreign antigens
  4. Complement system
  5. Trauma
questions.solution:
The complement system does not trigger an inflammatory response. It reacts against microbes and results in the production of mediators of inflammation.

The major triggers of inflammation include:

  • Infections - bacteria, viruses, fungi, parasites, toxins
  • Tissue necrosis - due to ischemia, trauma, physical or chemical injuries
  • Foreign bodies - 
    • Endogenous - DNA breakdown products (uric acid), cholesterol crystals, lipids
    • Exogenous - splinters, dirt, sutures, etc
  • Trauma
  • Immune reactions - against microbes, self-antigens, or environmental substances

questions.text:
Which of the following are cytosolic pattern-recognition receptors?
  1. Collectins
  2. NOD-like receptors
  3. Toll-like receptors
  4. RIG-like receptors
  5. Mannose-binding lectins
questions.solution:
NOD-like receptors and RIG-like receptors are cytosolic pattern-recognition receptors.

Pattern-recognition receptors are the cellular receptors that recognize microbes and damaged cells.

Types of pattern-recognition receptors:

  • Cellular receptors for microbes - 
    • Toll-like receptors on the plasma membrane and endosomal vesicles
    •  C-type lectin receptors on the plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells
  • Cytosolic receptors -
    • NOD-like receptors detect bacterial peptidoglycan
    • RIG-like receptors detect viral RNA
  • Circulating proteins: Mannose-binding lectin and collectins

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the acute inflammatory process?

choices.text: It is a mechanism of innate immunity
Monocytes and macrophages are mainly involved
Tissue injury is usually mild and self-limited
Local and systemic signs are prominent

questions.solution:
The prominent cells in acute inflammation are neutrophils.

The initial, rapid response to infections agents and tissue damage is called acute inflammation. It is a mechanism of innate immunity that occurs in response to mild and self-limited tissue injury. It is associated with prominent local and systemic signs.

The major components of acute inflammation are:

  • Vasodilation and increased permeability of small blood vessels 
  • Changes in the leukocytes -
    • Migration from the microcirculation
    • Accumulation at the site of inflammation
    • Activation to eliminate the offending agent

Chronic inflammation is a mechanism of adaptive immunity and is of longer duration. It is associated with

  • Presence of lymphocytes and macrophages
  • Proliferation of blood vessels
  • Deposition of connective tissue

questions.text: What is the most common mechanism of vascular leakage in acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
The most common mechanism of vascular leakage in acute inflammation is the contraction of endothelial cells.

This is an immediate, transient response mediated by histamine, bradykinin, and leukotrienes. The contraction of the endothelial cells results in an increase in the interendothelial spaces. 

Other mechanisms of vascular leakage include:

  • Endothelial injury - results in endothelial cell necrosis and detachment
  • Transcytosis - increased transport of fluids and proteins

questions.text: A man is brought to the casualty with swelling after sustaining a bee sting over his face. Which of the following vascular changes is not observed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Bee stings result in acute inflammation at the site of the sting. In this condition, there is decreased oncotic pressure due to protein leakage.

There is a release of inflammatory mediators like histamine which result in the following vascular changes: 

  • Vasodilation - results in erythema and stasis of blood flow
  • Increased vascular permeability -
    • Due to mediators like histamine, kinins, or endothelial injury (direct or leukocyte-induced ), or transcytosis
    • Results in leakage of proteins (reduced vascular oncotic pressure) and leukocyte migration 
  • Increased hydrostatic pressure - results in fluid leakage from blood vessels resulting in edema

The image below shows the changes seen during acute inflammation.

questions.text: During normal blood flow in venules, which cells occupy the central axial column?
questions.solution:
Blood flows in blood vessels as central axial/laminar column and peripheral chaotic columns. During normal blood flow in venules, the central axial column is occupied by the red blood cells (RBCs). 

These RBCs displace the leukocytes toward the wall of the vessel (chaotic column). During inflammation, stasis leads to slow blood flow and reduced wall shear stress. This further pushes the WBCs towards a peripheral position along the endothelial surface. This is called margination.

Subsequently, leukocytes adhere to the endothelium, then detach and bind again. This is referred to as rolling on the vessel wall. The cells finally come to rest and adhere firmly to the endothelial wall.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true with regard to selectins?

choices.text: There are L, E and P types of selectins
P-selectins are expressed on the endothelium

questions.solution:
Selectins are a group of molecules that mediate low-affinity interactions between the leukocytes and the endothelium.

Due to the low-affinity nature of these interactions, they are easily disrupted by the flowing blood. They play a major role in the initial rolling interactions of leukocytes with the vascular endothelium. The expression of selectins and their ligands is regulated by cytokines produced in response to infection and injury.

There are 3 types of selectins:

  1. L-selectin - expressed on leukocytes
  2. E-selectin - expressed on endothelium
  3. P-selectin - expressed on activated platelets and endothelium

questions.text: Which of the following is not an integrin molecule?
questions.solution:
CD 31 or platelet endothelial cell-adhesion molecule 1 (PECAM-1) is a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily. It is not an integrin molecule.

  • Selectin family - mediates initial rolling interactions between leukocytes and endothelium

    • Involved in migration and firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium
    • Includes LFA-1, MAC-1, and VLA-4
  • Immunoglobulin family -
    • PECAM (CD31) - most important adhesion molecule for diapedesis
    • ICAM-1 - binds to β2 integrins on leukocytes

questions.text: Which molecule plays a major role in the following phenomenon seen in leukocytes?
questions.solution:
The image shows diapedesis by leukocytes. CD31 or platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1) plays a major role in diapedesis. 

Diapedesis or transmigration refers to the migration of the leukocytes through the endothelium. It mainly occurs in postcapillary venules.

questions.text: In patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following cells are the major cause of tissue injury?
questions.solution:
In acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute tissue injury is caused mainly by neutrophils.

ARDS is a clinical syndrome manifested as a result of severe lung injury. The initiating event is alveolar epithelial cell damage. It is characterized by acute inflammation, causing increased pulmonary vascular permeability and edema. 

Neutrophils adhere to the activated endothelium and migrate into the interstitium and the alveoli. Here, they degranulate and release inflammatory mediators. These include:

  • Proteases
  • Reactive oxygen species
  • Cytokines

Macrophages are involved in the stage of resolution.

questions.text: Infection with which of the following organisms would produce an inflammatory infiltrate with neutrophilic predominance beyond 48 hours?
questions.solution:
In Pseudomonas infection, the inflammatory infiltrate has a neutrophilic predominance for several days.

Normally, in acute inflammation, neutrophils predominate the inflammatory infiltrate during the first 6 to 24 hours. However, they are short-lived, and disappear within 24 to 48 hours, following which they are replaced by monocytes.

Monocytes survive longer and also proliferate in the tissues. Thus, they become the dominant population in prolonged inflammatory reactions.

The exceptions to this pattern include:

  1. Pseudomonas infections - neutrophilic dominance in the infiltrate for several days
  2. Viral infections - lymphocytes are the initial cells
  3. Allergic reactions - eosinophils are the main cell type
  4. Some types of hypersensitivity - dominated by activated lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in inducing the migration of leukocytes to sites of injury?
questions.solution:
C5a induces the migration of leukocytes to the site of injury. It functions as an endogenous chemoattractant.

Both exogenous and endogenous substances can act as chemoattractants. The most common exogenous agents include bacterial products like peptides with N-formylmethionine terminal amino acids and certain lipids. 

Endogenous chemoattractants include several chemical mediators:

  1. Cytokines - particularly those of the chemokine family (IL-8)
  2. Complement system components - particularly C5a
  3. Arachidonic acid metabolites - mainly leukotriene B4 

Related Pearl: Various actions of Principal Mediators of Inflammation

questions.text: Which of the following is an opsonin?
questions.solution:
C3b functions as an opsonin.

Opsonization is the process of coating a foreign particle and preparing it for phagocytosis. The substances involved in this process are called opsonins and include: 

  • Mannose-binding lectin
  • C3b, C4b, C5b
  • IgM and Fc receptor of IgG
  • CRP
  • Fibrinogen

Elie Metchnikoff was the first person to describe the process of phagocytosis, and is hence known as the Father of Innate Immunity.

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have antioxidant action?
questions.solution:
Myeloperoxidase is an oxidative enzyme, not an antioxidant.

Antioxidants provide protection against potentially harmful oxygen-derived radicals. Serum, tissue fluids, and host cells possess antioxidant mechanisms. These include:

  • Catalase
  • Superoxide dismutase
  • Glutathione peroxidase 
  • Iron-free fraction of transferrin
  • Carotenoids
  • Ceruloplasmin

Myeloperoxidase is an oxidative enzyme with antimicrobial activity. It is seen in azurophil (primary) granules of neutrophils. It is involved in the production of hypochlorous acid and destroys microbes by means of halogenation and lipid peroxidation.

questions.text: Oxygen-dependent killing is done through which of the following?
questions.solution:
NADPH oxidase is involved in the oxygen-dependent killing of microbes. It results in generation of reactive oxygen intermediates.

This process is called the oxidative burst. It involves the generation of H2O2, and eventually hypochlorous acid. This H2O2-MPO-halide system is the most efficient bactericidal system of neutrophils.

Carotenoids, glutathione peroxidase, and the iron-free fraction of transferrin are antioxidants or free radical scavengers that prevent oxygen-mediated injury.

questions.text: A 7-month-old male infant was brought with a 2-day history of fever and abscess over the neck. The mother reveals that the child has had similar recurrent infections in the past. The result of the nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test was found to be abnormal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and abnormal nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test are suggestive of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD).

CGD is a rare primary immunodeficiency of phagocytes. It is an X-linked recessive disorder due to the deficiency in the NADPH oxidase enzyme. This is important in the respiratory or oxidative burst. 

It usually manifests in the first year of life with recurrent pyogenic infections with catalase-positive organisms, including: 

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Escherichia coli
  • Aspergillus species

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: A nitroblue tetrazolium test is performed in a child with recurrent infections. Functions of which of the following are assessed by this test?
questions.solution:
Nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) is done to assess the function of phagocytes.

The principle is based on the color change of the colorless nitroblue tetrazolium compound to a deep blue when exposed to reactive oxygen species (ROS). The higher the nitroblue test score, the better the cell is at producing ROS.

In chronic granulomatous disease, there is an NADPH oxidase defect. Hence, the phagocyte is unable to produce reactive oxygen species or radicals required for bacterial killing, which results in recurrent infections. Hence, there is a reduced color change with the NBT test.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions have defective phagolysosome formation?
questions.solution:
Defective phagolysosome formation is seen in patients with Chediak–Higashi syndrome (CHS). It is a rare autosomal recessive defect.

There is an abnormal fusion of azurophilic lysosomes of neutrophils and cytoplasmic granules of monocytes and lymphocytes, which leads to the presence of giant lysosomal granules. Hence, there is abnormal post-phagocytic phagolysosomal fusion, degranulation, and impaired microbicidal activity. There is rapid neutrophil turnover leading to low counts. 

Clinical features include:

  • Recurrent infections -
    • Commonly affect the skin, upper and lower respiratory tract
    • Common organisms - Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, Group A Streptococcus, Gram-negative enteric (Klebsiella, Proteus, Shigella, Pseudomonas)
  • Accelerated phase in some patients - 
    • Hemophagocytic syndrome and aggressive lymphoma
    • These patients require bone marrow transplantation
  • Albinism with neurological defects

questions.text: What is frustrated phagocytosis?

choices.text: Release of lysosomal contents due to damaged membrane
Engulfment of infectious pathogens and degradation by phagolysosome
Release of lysosomal enzymes when phagocytes cannot engulf targets

questions.solution:
The term frustrated phagocytosis refers to the release of large amounts of lysosomal contents into the external environment due the inability of the phagocytes to engulf.

When immune complexes are deposited on relatively flat immovable surfaces, the phagocytes are unable to surround and ingest them. In this case, the activation signals lead to an uncontrolled release of the lysosomal contents, despite lack of phagocytosis. This is known as frustrated phagocytosis. 

Other processes may lead to the release of lysosomal contents into the external environment:

  • Controlled secretion of granule contents - normal response of activated leukocytes
  • Damage to the phagolysosome membrane by certain phagocytosed substances like urate crystals

questions.text: What does the following image show?
questions.solution:
The image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis. Here, intact hematopoietic cells are seen within the cytoplasm of the host cell without any damage.

questions.text: In which of the following is major basic protein seen?
questions.solution:
The major basic protein is the predominant constituent of the crystalline core of the eosinophil granule.

It is also called proteoglycan-2 and is encoded by the PRG2 gene. This protein is involved in: 

  • Antiparasitic defense mechanisms - functions as a cytotoxin and helminthotoxin 
  • Immune hypersensitivity reactions
  • Lysis of epithelial cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs)?

choices.text: They prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils
Nuclear chromatin in the NETs are the source of nuclear antigens in SLE
In sepsis, platelet activation is involved in NET formation
NETs play a major role in phagocytosis

questions.solution:
Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are not involved in phagocytosis. This is because the nuclei of the neutrophils are lost during NET formation, leading to their death. Hence, they cannot phagocytose pathogens.

NETs are networks of extracellular fibers that consist of a viscous meshwork of nuclear chromatin. They trap microbes at sites of infection, preventing their further spread. They also contain a high concentration of antimicrobial proteins like neutrophil elastase, cathepsin G, and histones that have a high affinity for DNA.

They are produced by neutrophils in response to the following triggers:

  • Pathogens - Mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators -
    • Chemokines
    • Cytokines (mainly interferons)
    • Complement proteins
    • Reactive oxygen species

NETs have also been detected in the blood during sepsis. In this condition, platelet activation is involved in NET formation

The nuclear chromatin in the NETs is a source of nuclear antigens (histones and associated DNA) in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This triggers autoantibody production and further clinical manifestations.
